thread.title: What does the Brexit Supreme Court decision mean for triggering Article 50?
thread.title_full: What does the Brexit Supreme Court decision mean for triggering Article 50?

author: Mikey Smith
title: What does the Brexit Supreme Court decision mean for triggering Article 50?
text:
News What does the Brexit Supreme Court decision mean for triggering Article 50? Theresa May has been defeated in the Supreme Court - but what does that mean for Brexit? Here's everything you need to know Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Supreme Court judges decide MPs WILL get vote on Article 50 Share this video Get politics updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
MPs must be given a vote on triggering Article 50 , after a humiliating defeat for the government in the Supreme Court. 
The ruling, handed down by Supreme Court president Lord Neuberger this morning, means the Prime Minister will not be allowed to start the Brexit process without parliamentary scrutiny. 
He revealed the court voted by a majority of 8 to 3 to tell the Prime Minister she did not have the power to do it by herself. 
But what does it mean for the process of Brexit ? And what happens next? 
Here's everything you need to know after this morning's crunch Supreme Court ruling . Read More What does the judgement mean? (Photo: Getty) 
While the court agreed that the Government do generally have "prerogative" power - the power to act without consulting parliament. 
But the Supreme Court decided that in this case the government must pass an act of Parliament to trigger Article 50 . 
Their main reason was that when the UK joined the EU, the Union was able to create UK laws - and that can only be reversed with legislation. 
They also decided an act of parliament would be necessary because the rights of UK citizens would change. Read More Does this mean we won't be leaving the EU? 
No. (Photo: Rex Features) 
The Government must come forward and pass a law to trigger Article 50 . 
MPs and peers will be given a chance to debate, scrutinise and vote on the bill when it comes to Parliament. 
But it's thought the bill could be just two clauses long, which leaves little scope for MPs to offer amendments to the details. How long will the process take? (Photo: PA) 
Theresa May says even if Parliament does vote on Article 50 , she still intends to trigger it before the end of March. 
After that, the UK will remain a member for a period of two years before breaking away entirely from the EU. 
Negotiating deals with EU members and others could take years after that Will Scotland and Wales get to vote on it? (Photo: Jeff J Mitchell) 
No. 
The Supreme Court decided unanimously that it was for the UK parliament to vote on Britain's relationship with the EU, and it shouldn't be devolved to the regions. 
This will be a blow to Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon, who has said she wants Scotland to remain in the EU even when the Union exits. Will MPs and peers get a vote on Theresa May's deal? 
Yes. Theresa May has confirmed MPs will get to vote on the deal she manages to eke out with Brussels on Britain's relationship with Europe after Brexit . Read More
